title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 05
author: Various
snippet: There were about an equal number ofmen and women, but no children--these being left at Yetholm, where theyremained stationary during the winter months.

title: Guy Mannering, Or, the Astrologer - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 'I have ever understood,' he says, speaking of the Yetholmgipsies,' that they are extremely superstitious, carefullynoticing the formation of the clouds, the flight of particularbirds, and the soughing of the winds, before attempting anyenterprise.

title: Guy Mannering, Or, the Astrologer - Complete
author: Scott, Walter

title: Guy Mannering, Or, the Astrologer - Complete
author: Scott, Walter

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The Lord Hume of the latter period of the seventeenth century, had anatural son, Patrick, an arch rogue, inheriting the fire of the blood ofthe Humes, along with that which burnt in the black eyes of the gipsies ofYetholm.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: Melrose, theEildon Hills, the haunt of Thomas of Ercildoune, Jedburgh, Yetholm, theCowdenknowes, the Yarrow, and Ettrick, all lie on different sides withina circle of twenty miles, and most of them much nearer.

title: Critical and miscellaneous essays.
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Out comes the master, a rosy-cheeked carl, upwards of six feet high, broad-shouldered, with a blue bonnet and velveteen breeches, a man not to be jostled on the crown o' the causeway, and a match for any horse-couper from Bewcastle, or gipsy from Yetholm.
